The data captures the top 2000 companies in the world and is available for free upon registration on the [Kagle website](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/joebeachcapital/top-2000-companies-globally). We filter the data to only include companies from Africa. # **Objectives** The primary goal of this exercise is to illustrate how to use Python, pandas and other libraries in Python programming to analyse data for meaningful insights about large companies in Africa. Specifically, we seek to; 1. Rank companies in Africa by their performance. 2. Rank countries in Africa based on the concentration of large companies. 3. Compute the correlation between company size (in terms of assets) and financial performance. 4. Uncover regional patterns in company performance based on country. 5. Establish the companies, countries in Africa with the highest returns on assets and profit margins. # **Summary of Results** 1. Most large companies in the sample are located in South Africa. 2. Companies from South Africa have the highest sales, profits, asset base, and valuation. 4. Note that these are countries mainly from North America and Asia (with the exception of the UK) which illustrates the dominance of these two continents in global trade. ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company['country'].value_counts() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` South Africa 19 Morocco 2 Egypt 2 Nigeria 1 Liberia 1 Name: country, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company['continent'].value_counts() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ``` Africa 25 Name: continent, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: We then visualize this information on a world map using latitude and longitude data to show the geographic distribution of these companies. The size of the dots represents profits. We find that while there are the profitable companies are mainly in Asia, Europe, and North America. The rest of the world generates very few profits. ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} # Create a GeoDataFrame geometry = [Point(lon, lat) for lon, lat in zip(company['longitude'], company['latitude'])] gdf = gpd.GeoDataFrame(company, geometry=geometry, columns=['company', 'sales', 'profits', 'assets']) ``` ```` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} world = gpd.read_file(gpd.datasets.get_path('naturalearth_lowres')) ``` ```` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} #| fig-cap: "Top Companies by Sales on a World Map" # Create a subplot fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 10)) # Plot the world map world.boundary.plot(ax=ax, color = "lightgrey") # Plot your data on the map gdf.plot(ax=ax, marker='o', color='red', markersize='profits', label='Companies') # Add labels and legend ax.set_title('Top Companies in Africa by Profits on a Map') ax.set_xlabel('Longitude') ax.set_ylabel('Latitude') ax.legend() plt.show() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Top Companies by Sales on a World Map](africa_files/figure-html/cell-29-output-1.png){width=819 height=439} ::: ::: ## Is There a Correlation Between Company Size (in terms of assets) and Financial Performance? Here, we analyze the relationship between the asset base of companies, which is a proxy for size and financial metrics such as sales, profits, and market value. The goal is to determine if larger companies tend to have higher sales, profits, and market value, or if there are exceptions. Overall, there appears to be a positive link between the size of a company and its financial performance in terms of sales, profits, and market value. In this section, I group the data by country and analyze the average sales, profits, and assets for companies in each country. South African companies in the sample have by far the highest sales, profits, asset base, and market valuation . ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} #| fig-cap: "Sales by Companies" plt.style.use("fivethirtyeight") company.groupby("country")["sales"].sum().sort_values().plot(kind = "barh", title = "Total Sales of Top Companies in Africa by Country") ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=31} ``` ``` Sales by Companies ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](africa_files/figure-html/cell-32-output-2.png){width=789 height=459} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=32} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} #| fig-cap: "Total Profits of Top 2000 Companies globally by Continent" company.groupby("country")["profits"].sum().sort_values().plot(kind = "barh", title = "Total Profits of Top Companies in Africa by Country") ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ``` ``` Total Profits of Top 2000 Companies globally by Continent ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](africa_files/figure-html/cell-33-output-2.png){width=795 height=459} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=33} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} #| fig-cap: "Total Assets of Top 2000 Companies globally by Continent" company.groupby("country")["assets"].sum().sort_values().plot(kind = "barh", title = "Total Assets of Top Companies in Africa by Country") ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=33} ``` ``` Total Assets of Top 2000 Companies globally by Continent ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](africa_files/figure-html/cell-34-output-2.png){width=797 height=459} ::: ::: ## Which Companies, Contiments have the Highest Returns on Assets and Profit margins? The return on assets is the ratio of profits to assets and captures the efficiency with which a company utilises its assets to generate profits. The net profit margin also captures how well a company is able to convert its sales into profits. The margin can also proxy the management efforts towards expenses management. Dangote cement of Nigeria leads with a return on assets of 0.25. This is phenomenal!! The companies in the top 5 all have a return greater than 15%, which is an exceptional performance. ::: {.cell execution_count=34} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company["roa"] = company["profits"] / company["assets"] company["margin"] = company["profits"] / company["sales"] ``` ```` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=35} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company['roa'].sort_values(ascending = False).head() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=35} ``` company Dangote Cement 0.250000 Exxaro Resources 0.244898 Assore 0.238095 RMB Holdings 0.181818 Remgro 0.154930 Name: roa, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Next, I compute the median ROA for each continent. Nigeria leads, though the country has only one company in the sample. South Africa is in second place with a median ROA of 7%. ::: {.cell execution_count=36} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company.groupby("country")['roa'].median().sort_values(ascending = False) ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=36} ``` country Nigeria 0.250000 South Africa 0.072727 Egypt 0.045849 Morocco 0.008872 Liberia 0.000000 Name: roa, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Let us do the same for profit margin. RMB Holdings has a profit margin of 1 which implies that the company generated profits equal to sales. Overall, the conversion of sales to profits is impressive among the industry leaders. ::: {.cell execution_count=37} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company['margin'].sort_values(ascending = False).head() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ``` company RMB Holdings 1.000000 Exxaro Resources 0.800000 Remgro 0.647059 Dangote Cement 0.533333 Assore 0.312500 Name: margin, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Nigeria and Egypt leads in median profit margin. Again this could be die to the low number of companies from the coutries in this sample. ::: {.cell execution_count=38} ```` { .cell-code} ```{{python}} company.groupby("country")['margin'].median().sort_values(ascending = False) ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=38} ``` country Nigeria 0.533333 Egypt 0.164815 South Africa 0.139423 Morocco 0.126161 Liberia 0.000000 Name: margin, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: # **Conclusion** In this analysis, we use data from Kagle to illustrate the use of Python and Pandas in data analysis.
